metadata.title: CAP-Net: A Deep Learning-Based Angle Prediction Approach for ISAC-Enabled RIS-Assisted V2I Communications
metadata.venue: 2022 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Communication Technology (ICCT)
metadata.journal: 2022 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Communication Technology (ICCT)
metadata.abstract: In the vehicle-to-infrastructure (V2I) scenarios, it is challenging to acquire accurate channel state information (CSI) due to the high mobility of the communication channels, which leads to considerable pilot overhead. To tackle this issue, we employ both integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) technique and reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) technique to reduce the pilot overhead significantly while maximizing the achievable rate. In particular, we consider a RIS-assisted ISAC system serving the vehicle and design a transmission protocol based on communication-sensing-computing integration architecture for the proposed system, where the ISAC base station (BS) and the dedicated sensors deployed at the RIS receive the reflected echo signals from the user equipment (UE) via the BS-UE-BS link and the BS-UE-sensors link, respectively. Then the CSI of the UE can be acquired from the received signals. Furthermore, to provide both high-quality and low-latency communication services, we propose a covariance-based angle prediction neural network (CAP-Net) to predict the angle parameters facilitating the joint transmit and reflective beamforming design for the next time slot. Simulation results show that the proposed RIS-assisted ISAC system with the CAP-Net achieves better communication performance compared with other baseline schemes and can approach the upper bound in terms of achievable rate.

grobid.contents:
CAP-Net: A Deep Learning-Based Angle Prediction Approach for ISAC-Enabled RIS-Assisted V2I Communications


Ruixiang Wang 
School of Information and Electronics
Beijing Institute of Technology (BIT)
100081BeijingChina

School of Beijing Institute of Technology (Jiaxing)
Yangtze River Delta Graduate
314000JiaxingChina

Fanghao Xia xiafanghaoxfh@163.com 
School of Information and Electronics
Beijing Institute of Technology (BIT)
100081BeijingChina

Jingxuan Huang 
School of Information and Electronics
Beijing Institute of Technology (BIT)
100081BeijingChina

Zesong Fei feizesong@bit.edu.cn. 
School of Information and Electronics
Beijing Institute of Technology (BIT)
100081BeijingChina

CAP-Net: A Deep Learning-Based Angle Prediction Approach for ISAC-Enabled RIS-Assisted V2I Communications
10.1109/ICCT56141.2022.10072562
In the vehicle-to-infrastructure (V2I) scenarios, it is challenging to acquire accurate channel state information (CSI) due to the high mobility of the communication channels, which leads to considerable pilot overhead. To tackle this issue, we employ both integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) technique and reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) technique to reduce the pilot overhead significantly while maximizing the achievable rate. In particular, we consider a RIS-assisted ISAC system serving the vehicle and design a transmission protocol based on communication-sensing-computing integration architecture for the proposed system, where the ISAC base station (BS) and the dedicated sensors deployed at the RIS receive the reflected echo signals from the user equipment (UE) via the BS-UE-BS link and the BS-UE-sensors link, respectively. Then the CSI of the UE can be acquired from the received signals. Furthermore, to provide both high-quality and low-latency communication services, we propose a covariance-based angle prediction neural network (CAP-Net) to predict the angle parameters facilitating the joint transmit and reflective beamforming design for the next time slot. Simulation results show that the proposed RIS-assisted ISAC system with the CAP-Net achieves better communication performance compared with other baseline schemes and can approach the upper bound in terms of achievable rate.Index Terms-Integrated sensing and communication (ISAC), reconfigurable intelligent surface, deep learning, vehicle-toinfrastructure (V2I) communications.

I. INTRODUCTION

In the era of beyond 5G and 6G, it is expected that the sensing functionality is integrated into the current wireless communication systems as a new feature, serving the emerging application scenarios such as vehicle-to-everything (V2X) networks. Integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) is a promising technique that can provide integration or coordination gains for the sensing and communication services [1]. In addition, ISAC is deemed to achieve high spectral efficiency and low hardware cost via integrating two functionalities into a single system [2].

In particular, since the communication channels are highly dynamic in the vehicle-to-infrastructure (V2I) scenarios, it is challenging to acquire the real-time channel state information (CSI) of the vehicles. To address this issue, there have been several works studying ISAC-enabled V2I communications. The works in [3]- [5] employed the ISAC signal to realize V2I beam tracking and prediction. With the ISAC signal, various beam prediction methods were utilized, such as extended Kalman filtering in [3], factor graph in [4], and deep learning in [5]. The above works show the great superiority of the ISAC-based scheme over the conventional communicationonly scheme in terms of reducing the pilot overhead. However, They only considered the line-of-sight (LoS) link between the roadside units and the user equipment (UE), while the non-LoS (NLoS) paths that facilitate communication were not fully exploited.

Reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS), consisting of a large number of reflecting elements, can independently adjust the amplitude and phase shift of each element to reconfigure the wireless environment [6], [7]. The RIS is typically deployed in the NLoS region to create a virtual LoS link between the transmitter and receiver, which is useful for both sensing and communication. There are already several works on RISassisted ISAC system. In [8], [9], the RIS was employed to minimize multi-user interference under the constraints of beampattern and Cramér-Rao bound, respectively. Furthermore, the RIS-related CSI can be obtained with the aid of the ISAC by estimating the parameters of the UEs, which can be used for the reflective beamforming design. However, it should be noted that in the conventional mono-static sensing scenario, the base station (BS) acts as the mono-static radar and the acquisition of RIS-related CSI is based on the BS-RIStarget-RIS-BS link. Thus, the echo signals will suffer severe attenuation due to the high path loss. To address this problem, the authors in [10] designed a self-sensing RIS architecture to mitigate the impact of path loss by reducing the reflection hops, while they simply focused on the sensing performance without concern for the communication performance.

In this paper, motivated by the above works, we propose a novel RIS-assisted ISAC system serving the vehicle, where the CSI of the UE can be obtained by the received echo signals to reduce the pilot overhead and improve the communication rate. First, we design a a transmission protocol based on communication-sensing-computing integration architecture for the proposed system.  Fig. 1. The RIS-assisted ISAC system. next time slot, we propose a covariance-based angle prediction neural network (CAP-Net). The CAP-Net is composed of the convolutional neural network (CNN) and the long short-term memory (LSTM) network, which is exploited to predict angles of arrival (AoAs) based on historical covariance matrices of the received echo signals. Finally, the transmit and reflective beamforming can be jointly optimized to achieve higher communication rate.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section II provides the RIS-assisted ISAC system model and the transmission protocol. The proposed CAP-Net is described in Section III. Simulation results are shown in Section IV and the conclusion is given in Section V.

Notations: a, a, A denote complex scalar value, vector, matrix, respectively; C represents the set of complex numbers; [·] * , [·] T , and [·] H denote the conjugate, transpose and conjugate-transpose operations, respectively; || and ∥·∥ denotes the absolute value and the Euclidean norm, respectively; N µ, σ 2 and CN µ, σ 2 denotes the Gaussian and complex Gaussian distributions with mean µ and variance σ 2 , respectively.


II. SYSTEM MODEL

As shown in Fig. 1, we consider a narrow-band RIS-assisted ISAC system, where a single-antenna vehicular UE is served by the BS and the RIS simultaneously. The BS is equipped with a uniform linear array (ULA) with M t transmit antennas and M r receive antennas. For notational simplicity, we assume M t = M r = M . Thanks to the full-duplex technique [1], the BS can perform downlink communication and single-target sensing via the LoS link, i.e., BS-UE-BS link. In addition, the RIS is comprised of N = N h * N v passive reflection elements to provide an additional LoS link, i.e., BS-RIS-UE link, where N h and N v denote the number of elements in the horizontal and vertical directions, respectively. The BS and the RIS are connected via the optical cable to realize real-time information sharing and synchronization. Moreover, to acquire the CSI between the RIS and the UE, (N h +N v +1) dedicated sensors are deployed at the margin of the RIS to receive the reflected echo signals via the BS-UE-sensors link. The coordinates of the BS and the RIS are expressed as
L b = [x b , y b , z b ]
T and L r = [x r , y r , z r ] T , respectively. In the time slot t ∈ T , where T represents the set of time slots of interest, the location of the moving UE, i.e.,
L u [t] = [x u [t], y u [t], z u [t]]
T , is given by
L u [t] = L u [t − 1] + v[t − 1]∆T,(1)
where v[t − 1] and ∆T donote the velocity of the UE in the time slot t − 1 and the time duration of each time slot, respectively. To simplify the expressions, we omit the notation t in following subsections. In addtion, we omit the Doppler parameters with the assumption that the UE is located in the same Doppler bin all the time.


A. MISO Communication Model

We consider the downlink communication from the BS to the UE, the received signal y c at the UE is
y c = (h ru ΘH br + h bu ) ws + n u ,(2)
where s = [s 1 , s 2 , · · · , s L ] ∈ C 1×L is the ISAC vector with L being the length of communication symbols, w ∈ C M ×1 denotes the transmit beamforming vector, and n u ∈ C 1×L is the noise vector obeying CN 0, σ 2 u I 1×L at the UE's receiver. Moreover, Θ denotes the reflection matrix of the RIS and H br ∈ C N ×M is the baseband equivalent channel of the BS-RIS link.

Note that the estimatedĤ br is assumed to be known since it is quasi-static and can be acquired by the proposed channel esitmation method in [11] with low pilot overhead. In addition, h bu ∈ C 1×M and h ru ∈ C 1×N denote baseband equivalent channels of the BS-UE link and RIS-UE link, where h bu can be modeled as
h bu = α bu u T (ϕ bu , M ) ,(3)
where, α bu = λ 4πd bu represents the complex-valued channel coefficient with λ being the carrier wavelength and d bu being the distance beween the BS and the UE; u (ϕ bu , M ) denotes the transmit steering vector, where ϕ bu ∆ = 2πdc λ sin (φ bu ), d c is antenna spacing, and φ bu is the azimuth angle from the BS to the UE. Therein, the steering vector function u φ ,N is defined as
u φ ,N = 1, e −jφ , · · · , e −jnφ · · · , e −j(N −1)φ T ,(4)
whereφ denotes the phase delay between two adjacent elements andN is the number of elements in the array. Similar to (3), the RIS-UE channel is given by
h ru = α ru [u (ϕ ru,h , N h ) ⊗ u (ϕ ru,v , N v )] T ,(5)
where α ru = λ 4πdru denotes the channel coefficient with d ru being the distance beween the RIS and the UE, ϕ ru,h
∆ = 2πdc λ sin (φ ru,h ) sin (φ ru,v ), and ϕ ru,v ∆ = 2πdc
λ cos (φ ru,v ). Here, φ ru,h and φ ru,v represent the azimuth and elevation angles from the RIS to the UE, respectively.

According to (2), the SNR of the UE's received signal is given as
γ = |(h ru ΘH br + h bu ) w| 2 σ 2 u .(6)
The achievable rate is given as
R = log 2 (1 + γ) .(7)

B. Sensing Model

We consider a sensing system where the ISAC signal is transmitted by the BS, reflected by the UE, and finally received by BS and sensors, respectively. Here, we assume that the signals undergoing the multiple-reflected links, i.e., BS-RIS-UE-BS link and BS-RIS-UE-sensors link, can be neglected due to the severe path-loss. Moreover, the interference signals via the BS-sensors link are assumed to be eliminated using the space-time adaptive processing [12]. The BS-UE-sensors echo link in the horizontal direction can be modeled as
H bus,h = α bus u (ϕ ru,h , N h ) u T (ϕ bu , M ) ,(8)
where u (ϕ ru,h , N h ) is the receive steering vector of the horizontal sensors, α bus =
λ 2 σRCS 64π 3 d 2 bu d 2 ru
is the complex gain and σ RCS denotes the radar cross section (RCS). Then, the echo signal received by the horizontal sensors is given as
Y bus,h = H bus,h ws + n s,h ,(9)
where n s,h ∼ CN 0, σ 2 s I N h ×L denotes the noise at the horizontal sensors with L being the length of snapshots. The echo signals received by BS and vertical sensors can be modeled similarly.

To conclude, the overall received echo signal for the proposed sensing system is given as
Y r = H r ws + n r ,(10)
where 
Y r = [Y bub , Y bus,

C. Transmission Protocol

Conventional channel estimation schemes generally depend on uplink pilots from the UE. For highly dynamic channels, uplink pilots are required to send frequently to guarantee the accuracy of the channel estimation, thus leading to high pilot overhead. Fortunately, the pilot overhead can be significantly reduced with the aid of the ISAC technique. Driven by this, a transmission protocol based on communication-sensingcomputing integration architecture is proposed. Fig. 2 shows the proposed transmission protocol and conventional communication-only transmission protocol. The location of the UE and channel coefficients are assumed to remain constant within a time slot. Specifically, an example in Consider the impact of the round-trip time delay, we employ the partial received echo signal Y r ∈ C K×Lp with L p snapshots to ensure that the parameters estimation and prediction can be performed within a time slot. The covariance matrix of Y r is given by 
R Y = 1 L p Y r Y r H .(11)

III. PROPOSED COVARIANCE-BASED ANGLE PREDICTION NEURAL NETWORK FOR AOAS PREDICTION

Note that the accurate AoAs prediction is of great importance for the joint beamforming design. Therefore, in this section, we design a deep neural network (DNN) based on CNN-LSTM architecture, named CAP-Net, which is employed to realize the nonlinear mapping from historical covariance matrices of the received echo signals over τ slots to predicted 
Y [ 1] t  − + R Y [ 1] t − R Y [ ] t R

1]

t  + Fig. 3. The proposed CAP-Net for AoAs prediction. AoAs, where the inspiration comes from subspace reconstruction methods. In addition, we choose the low-dimensional AoAs rather than the high-dimensional steering vectors as the output of CAP-Net to reduce the time complexity and guarantee efficiency. The architecture of CAP-Net is shown in Fig. 3, which comprises one input layer, one CNN model, one LSTM model, and a fully-connected (FC) layer. First, the historical covariance matrices of the received echo signals over τ time slots are split into the real part and the imaginary part as the network's input, which is given as
R τ Y = [ℜ {R τ Y } , ℑ {R τ Y }] ,(12)where R τ Y = {R Y [t − τ + 1], R Y [t − τ + 2], ..., R Y [t]}.
Then, the CNN model is utilized to extract the spatial features from the noisy covariance matrices. To reduce the dimensionality, the MaxPooling layer is connected to each convolutional layer. Furthermore, the Flatten layers are used to vectorize the data matrices for LSTM layers. The LSTM model can be leveraged to learn the representations of both short-term and long-term temporal correlations of the extracted features from the CNN model and determine which part of correlation information is saved and passed to the next time step. In addition, the activation function of convolutional layers and the first LSTM layer are rectified linear units (ReLU). Moreover, the second LSTM layer adopts the Sigmoid activation function. Finally, a FC layer is connected to obtain the predicted AoAs as the network's output, i.e.,φ[t + 1]. Thus, the mapping function Ξ can be expressed aŝ
φ[t + 1] = Ξ R Y ; ξ Y ,(13)
where ξ Y denotes the DNN parameters, which can be updated by the ADAM algorithm to minimize the loss function in the off-line training phase. Here we select the mean squared error (MSE) as the loss function, which is given by
L(ξ Y ) = 1 N s Ns i=1 Ξ R τ (i) Y ; ξ Y − φ (i) [t + 1] 2 2 ,(14)
whereR τ (i) Y denotes the i-th sample in the N s training samples, and φ (i) [t + 1] is the label corresponding to the outputφ (i) [t+1] of the network. The layer structure and hyper parameters of the CAP-Net are shown in TABLE I.

The aforementioned well-trained network can be used to obtain the predicted AOAs in the online prediction phase, which facilitate the joint transmit and reflective beamforming design for the next time slot.


IV. SIMULATION RESULTS

In this section, we provide numerical results to evaluate the performance of the proposed CAP-Net in the RIS-assisted ISAC system, where the BS and the RIS are located at L b = [0, 0, 10] and L r = [0, 60, 5]. We assume that the initial location of the UE is L u [1] = [−15, 56, 2], the time duration for each time slot is ∆T = 0.02s, the cardinality of the set T is 150, and the speed of the UE is
v = [v x , 0, 0],
where v x is a random variable following the uniform distribution, ranging from 12 m/s to 12.5 m/s. Unless otherwise specified, the number of BS antenna and RIS element is set as M = 16 and N v = N h = 25, respectively. The transmit power is P t = 20 dBm, and the noise at the receiver is set as
σ 2 u = σ 2 b = σ 2 s = −90 dBm.
The carrier wavelength is 0.01m, the RCS is assumed as σ RCS = 10 + 10j, L is 120 and L p is 100. The number of time slots as the input of the CAP-Net (i.e., τ ) is 5, and the acquisition of all the simulation results is averaged over 1000 Monte-Carlo experiments.

To validate the effectiveness of the CAP-net in the RISassisted ISAC system, we consider the following schemes for Here, we assume that the acquired CSI is perfect at the cost of 8% temporal resources [13]. In Fig. 4, we show the achievable rate of all schemes versus the x-coordinate of the UE's location (i.e., x u ). First, it can be observed that the proposed CAP-Net scheme can achieve higher achievable rate compared with other schemes and can approach the upper bound. Moreover, the achievable rate is significantly improved when the UE moves near the RIS due to path-loss reduction of the RIS-UE link. Second, for the classic MUSIC scheme, it is worth noting that the achievable rate decreases as the UE is close to the RIS. The reason is that both the azimuth and elevation angles change drastically in this case, thus, joint beamforming design based on the outdated AoAs will lead to incorrect optimization results. In particular, the performance of misaligned beamforming is even worse than the scheme without the RIS when the UE is near the point where x u = 0. Fortunately, this problem can be tackled by channel prediction via the proposed CAP-Net, which can achieve the near-optimal communication rate under the current setup. Finally, for the pilot-based scheme, we observe that its achievable rate is inferior to that of other schemes. It demonstrates that the ISAC system can save considerable temporal resources by sensing-assisted communication from a long-term perspective. Fig. 5 illustrates the average achievable rate over all the time slots versus the number of reflecting elements N . Note that for the schemes with RIS, the average achievable rate increases with growing the number of reflecting elements due to more available spatial degrees of freedom. Similar to Fig. 4, the proposed CAP-Net outperforms all the other schemes while being relatively close to the upper bound. Furthermore, the gap of the proposed CAP-Net against other schemes (except the upper bound) grows as the number of reflecting elements increases.


V. CONCLUSIONS

In this paper, we considered a RIS-assisted ISAC system in the V2I scenario and design a transmission protocol based on communication-sensing-computing integration architecture, where the ISAC BS cooperates with the dedicated sensors deployed at the margin of the RIS to sense the vehicle and extract the CSI of the UE from the received echo signals without pilot overhead. Moreover, to guarantee accurate beam tracking in the high-mobility V2I scenario, we proposed a CAP-Net that has the capability of providing predictive AoAs to facilitate the joint transmit and reflective beamforming design for the next time slot. Simulation results show that the proposed RIS-assisted ISAC system with the CAP-Net is superior to other baseline schemes and approaches the upper bound in terms of achievable rate.


The work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China under Grant U20B2039. The corresponding author is Jingxuan Huang.
